problems.title: MAD Interactive Problem
problems.statementHtml:
This is an interactive problem.

There is a secret sequence a1,a2,…,a2n−1,a2na1,a2,…,a2n−1,a2n, which contains each integer from 11 to nn exactly twice.

Your task is to guess the sequence by using queries of the following type:

We define the MADMAD (Maximum Appearing Duplicate) of an integer sequence as the largest integer that appears at least twice. Specifically, if there is no number that appears at least twice, the MADMAD value is 00. Some examples are as follows:

Please identify the secret sequence using at most 3n3n queries.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤30001≤t≤3000). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains one integer nn (2≤n≤3002≤n≤300).

It is guaranteed that the sum of n2n2 over all test cases does not exceed 105105.

After you read this line of input, the interaction begins with your first query.

Interaction

To make a query, output a line (without quotes) in the following format:

  • "? kj1j2…jkkj1j2…jk" (1≤k≤2n1≤k≤2n, 1≤j1,j2,…,jk≤2n1≤j1,j2,…,jk≤2n)

Here, the indices j1,j2,…,jkj1,j2,…,jk which you selected must be pairwise distinct.

Then, after each query, read a single integer — the answer to your query.

You can make at most 3n3n queries of this type.

If your program has found the sequence aa, print the line (without quotes) in the following format:

  • "! a1a2…a2n−1a2na1a2…a2n−1a2n" (1≤ai≤n1≤ai≤n)

Note that this does not count towards the query limit.

After this, proceed to the next test case, or exit if this is the last test case.

The interactor in this task is not adaptive. In other words, the sequence aa does not change during the interaction.

If you make more than 3n3n queries during an interaction, your program must terminate immediately, and you will receive the Wrong Answer verdict. Otherwise, you can get an arbitrary verdict because your solution will continue to read from a closed stream.

After printing each line, do not forget to output the end of line and flush the output buffer. Otherwise, you will receive the Idleness Limit Exceeded verdict. To flush, use:

  • fflush(stdout) or cout.flush() in C++;
  • System.out.flush() in Java;
  • stdout.flush() in Python;
  • see the documentation for other languages.

Hacks

To make a hack, please use the following format:

The first line should contain the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤30001≤t≤3000).

The first line of each test case should contain an integer nn (2≤n≤3002≤n≤300).

The following line should contain 2n2n integers a1,a2,…,a2na1,a2,…,a2n (1≤ai≤n1≤ai≤n). Each number from 11 through nn must appear exactly twice.

The sum of n2n2 over all test cases should not exceed 105105.

For example, the hack format corresponding to the example interaction is as follows. 

2
2
2 2 1 1
2
1 2 1 2
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, the hidden sequence is a=[2,2,1,1]a=[2,2,1,1].

For the query "? 2 2 1", the jury returns 22 because MAD([a2,a1])=MAD([2,2])=2MAD⁡([a2,a1])=MAD⁡([2,2])=2.

For the query "? 2 1 3", the jury returns 00 because MAD([a1,a3])=MAD([2,1])=0MAD⁡([a1,a3])=MAD⁡([2,1])=0.

For the query "? 3 1 3 4", the jury returns 11 because MAD([a1,a3,a4])=MAD([2,1,1])=1MAD⁡([a1,a3,a4])=MAD⁡([2,1,1])=1.

Note that the example interaction is only for understanding statements and does not guarantee finding a unique sequence aa.

problems.title: Rectangles
problems.statementHtml:
You are given a binary grid∗∗ GG of dimensions n×mn×m.

Let us define a rectangle as a tuple (u,d,l,r)(u,d,l,r) that satisfies the following conditions:

Then, the area of a rectangle (u,d,l,r)(u,d,l,r) is defined as (d−u+1)⋅(r−l+1)(d−u+1)⋅(r−l+1).

For example, consider the following binary grid given below.

101011010000101

110000111000101

Here, you may see two rectangles (1,2,1,3)(1,2,1,3) and (1,3,3,5)(1,3,3,5)††, each of which has area 66 and 99, respectively.

For each cell (i,j)(i,j), find the minimum area of any rectangle (u,d,l,r)(u,d,l,r) such that u≤i≤du≤i≤d and l≤j≤rl≤j≤r.

∗∗A binary grid is a grid where each cell contains 00 or 11. The cell on the jj-th column of the ii-th row is denoted as cell (i,j)(i,j).

††Note that these are the only rectangles in the grid; for example, (1,1,1,5)(1,1,1,5) is not a rectangle as it does not satisfy u<du<d.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and mm (2≤n,m2≤n,m, n⋅m≤250000n⋅m≤250000).

Each of the nn following lines contains a string of length mm denoting the ii-th row of GG (Gi,j∈{0,1}Gi,j∈{0,1}).

It is guaranteed that the sum of n⋅mn⋅m over all test cases does not exceed 250000250000.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output a grid of nn rows and mm columns. On the jj-th column of the ii-th row, you should output:

  • If there exists a rectangle (u,d,l,r)(u,d,l,r) such that u≤i≤du≤i≤d and l≤j≤rl≤j≤r, output the minimum area of any such rectangle;
  • Otherwise, output 00 instead.
problems.noteHtml:
The first test case is explained in the statement.

For the third test case, there are six rectangles that cover at least one cell with minimum area:

  • (1,3,1,2)(1,3,1,2), which has area 66;
  • (1,2,1,3)(1,2,1,3), which has area 66;
  • (3,4,2,3)(3,4,2,3), which has area 44;
  • (2,3,3,4)(2,3,3,4), which has area 44;
  • (3,5,4,5)(3,5,4,5), which has area 66;
  • (4,5,3,5)(4,5,3,5), which has area 66.

problems.title: Twin Polynomials
problems.statementHtml:
A polynomial f(x)=a0+a1x+a2x2+…+anxnf(x)=a0+a1x+a2x2+…+anxn is called a valid polynomial of degree nn if and only if aiai is a non-negative integer for all 0≤i≤n0≤i≤n and anan is not 00.

For a valid polynomial f(x)=a0+a1x+a2x2+…+anxnf(x)=a0+a1x+a2x2+…+anxn of degree nn, its twin polynomial g(x)g(x) is defined as:

g(x)=∑i=0ni⋅xaig(x)=∑i=0ni⋅xai
For example, for f(x)=1+2x+2x3f(x)=1+2x+2x3, its twin polynomial is:

g(x)=0⋅x1+1⋅x2+2⋅x0+3⋅x2=0+x2+2+3x2=2+4x2g(x)=0⋅x1+1⋅x2+2⋅x0+3⋅x2=0+x2+2+3x2=2+4x2

A valid polynomial f(x)f(x) of degree nn is called cool if and only if f(x)=g(x)f(x)=g(x). In other words, a valid polynomial of degree nn is cool if and only if its twin polynomial equals itself.

You are given an incomplete valid polynomial f(x)=a0+a1x+a2x2+…+anxnf(x)=a0+a1x+a2x2+…+anxn of degree nn. Some of aiai have been determined, while others have not been determined. Additionally, it is guaranteed that a0a0 and anan are not determined.

Please count the number of cool valid polynomials of degree nn that can be found by determining all undetermined aiai's. Since the answer may be large, you need to output it modulo 10000000071000000007.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

For each test case, the first line contains an integer nn (1≤n≤4⋅1051≤n≤4⋅105).

The second line contains n+1n+1 integers a0,a1,…,ana0,a1,…,an (−1≤ai≤109−1≤ai≤109). Here, ai=−1ai=−1 means aiai has not been determined, while ai≠−1ai≠−1 means aiai has been determined as its value.

It is guaranteed that a0a0 and anan are always −1−1 in the input.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 4⋅1054⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output the number of cool valid polynomials of degree nn found by determining the undetermined aiai's, modulo 10000000071000000007.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, only f(x)=xf(x)=x satisfies the condition above.

In the second test case, only f(x)=x2+2xf(x)=x2+2x satisfies the condition above.

In the third test case, f(x)=2x2+xf(x)=2x2+x, f(x)=x2+2xf(x)=x2+2x, and f(x)=2x2+1f(x)=2x2+1 satisfy the condition above.

problems.title: Inverse Minimum Partition (Easy Version)
problems.statementHtml:
This is the easy version of the problem. The difference between the versions is that in this version, you are only asked to find f(a). You can hack only if you solved all versions of this problem.

For some sequence b of k positive integers, the cost of the sequence is defined as follows∗:

cost(b)=⌈bkmin(b1,b2,…,bk)⌉

Assume that you partition a sequence c into one or more sequences, so that the sequences become c when concatenated. For example, when the sequence c is [3,1,4,1,5], a few valid ways to partition the sequence are [[3,1],[4,1,5]], [[3],[1,4,1],[5]], [[3,1,4,1,5]]. On the other hand, [[3,1],[1,5]] and [[3,4,1],[1,5]] are not valid ways to partition the sequence.

For a partition of a sequence c of positive integers, the total cost of the partition is defined as the sum of the costs of each sequence in the partition. Then, let us define f(c) as the minimum total cost to partition the sequence c.

Given a sequence a of n positive integers, you must compute the value of f(a).

∗Given a real value x, ⌈x⌉ is defined as the smallest integer no less than x. For example, the value of ⌈3.14⌉ is 4.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases t (1≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer n (1≤n≤4⋅105).

The second line of each test case contains a1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤1018).

It is guaranteed that the sum of n over all test cases does not exceed 4⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output the answer to the problem on a separate line.
problems.noteHtml:
For the first test case, the partition [[3,1,4,1],[5]] gives a total cost of 1+1=2.

For the second test case, the partition [[9,2,6,5,3],[5,8,9,7,9]] gives a total cost of 2+2=4.

For the third test case, the partition [[1],[2,3,4],[5,6,7,8]] gives a total cost of 1+2+2=5.

For the fourth test case, the partition [[1],[1000000000000000000]] gives a total cost of 1+1=2.

problems.title: Inverse Minimum Partition (Hard Version)
problems.statementHtml:
This is the hard version of the problem. The difference between the versions is that in this version, you are asked to find the sum of f(b)f(b) over all contiguous subsequences bb of aa. You can hack only if you solved all versions of this problem.

For some sequence bb of kk positive integers, the cost of the sequence is defined as follows∗∗:

cost(b)=⌈bkmin(b1,b2,…,bk)⌉

Assume that you partition a sequence c into one or more sequences, so that the sequences become c when concatenated. For example, when the sequence c is [3,1,4,1,5], a few valid ways to partition the sequence are [[3,1],[4,1,5]], [[3],[1,4,1],[5]], [[3,1,4,1,5]]. On the other hand, [[3,1],[1,5]] and [[3,4,1],[1,5]] are not valid ways to partition the sequence.

For a partition of a sequence c of positive integers, the total cost of the partition is defined as the sum of the costs of each sequence in the partition. Then, let us define f(c) as the minimum total cost to partition the sequence c.

Given a sequence a of n positive integers, you must compute the following:

n∑l=1n∑r=lf([al,al+1,…,ar])

∗Given a real value x, ⌈x⌉ is defined as the smallest integer no less than x. For example, the value of ⌈3.14⌉ is 4.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases t (1≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer n (1≤n≤4⋅105).

The second line of each test case contains a1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤1018).

It is guaranteed that the sum of n over all test cases does not exceed 4⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output the answer to the problem on a separate line.
problems.noteHtml:
For the first test case, the following are all contiguous subsequences of a and their corresponding values:

  • [3]→[[3]]: f([3])=1;
  • [3,1]→[[3,1]]: f([3,1])=1;
  • [3,1,4]→[[3,1],[4]]: f([3,1,4])=2;
  • [3,1,4,1]→[[3,1,4,1]]: f([3,1,4,1])=1;
  • [3,1,4,1,5]→[[3,1,4,1],[5]]: f([3,1,4,1,5])=2;
  • [1]→[[1]]: f([1])=1;
  • [1,4]→[[1],[4]]: f([1,4])=2;
  • [1,4,1]→[[1,4,1]]: f([1,4,1])=1;
  • [1,4,1,5]→[[1,4,1],[5]]: f([1,4,1,5])=2;
  • [4]→[[4]]: f([4])=1;
  • [4,1]→[[4,1]]: f([4,1])=1;
  • [4,1,5]→[[4,1],[5]]: f([4,1,5])=2;
  • [1]→[[1]]: f([1])=1;
  • [1,5]→[[1],[5]]: f([1,5])=2;
  • [5]→[[5]]: f([5])=1.

Therefore, the answer for the first test case is 1+1+2+1+2+1+2+1+2+1+1+2+1+2+1=21.

problems.title: Super-Short-Polynomial-San
problems.statementHtml:
You are given three integers a,b,c.

Let F(n) be the polynomial of degree 2n defined as follows.

F(n)=(ax2+bx+c)n

You are asked to solve q queries of the following kind.

However, it might be too easy for you if this problem ends here. So here is a twist†: You are asked to solve the queries online.

∗Here, [xa]F(n) denotes the coefficient of xa of the polynomial F(n).

†I hope it isn't too hard for you after the twist. Even a toddler knows one way to solve it. You just have to optimize that method by a factor of 8000000.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains three integers a, b, c (1≤a,b,c≤109+6).

The second line contains the number of queries q (1≤q≤3⋅105).

Each of the q following lines contains two integers n′i and k′i denoting the query in encrypted format.

You must decrypt the queries as follows.

  • Let the answer to the i-th query modulo 109+7 be ansi. Here, ans0 is defined to be 0.
  • Then, the values of n and k for the i-th query are ni=n′i⊕ansi−1 and ki=k′i⊕ansi−1 (0≤ni≤3⋅105, 0≤ki≤2ni).

Do note that both the sum of ni and the sum of ki over all queries are not bounded.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each query, print the answer modulo 109+7 on a new line.
problems.noteHtml:
The decrypted example input is as follows. 

3 2 1
11
0 0
1 0
1 1
1 2
2 0
2 1
2 2
2 3
2 4
31415 9265
200000 69420

Here, the polynomial F(n) corresponds to A084608 from OEIS. Don't worry about the link; there's nothing so useful there. Trust me.

problems.title: Grand Finale: Snakes
problems.statementHtml:
This is an interactive problem.

You are given an integer nn and an n×nn×n grid of numbers GG. The grid of numbers contains each number from 11 to n2n2 exactly once.

Let's define a snake of length ll as a deque [(x1,y1),(x2,y2),…,(xl,yl)][(x1,y1),(x2,y2),…,(xl,yl)], where (x1,y1)(x1,y1) is the head of the snake, and (xl,yl)(xl,yl) is the tail. At second 11, x1=x2=…=xl=1x1=x2=…=xl=1 and yi=iyi=i for all 1≤i≤l1≤i≤l. In other words, the snake is entirely located in the first row, with the head at (1,1)(1,1) and the rest of the snake to the right of the head.

Each subsequent second, the snake moves down or right in the grid. Formally, the tail (xl,yl)(xl,yl) is removed, and either (x1+1,y1)(x1+1,y1) or (x1,y1+1)(x1,y1+1) is added as the new head. The first move of the snake is always downwards. It can be shown that the snake will never intersect itself under these restrictions. The snake will move exactly 2n−22n−2 times, never moving outside the grid. At second 2n−12n−1, the head reaches (n,n)(n,n), and the movement stops. It can be shown that the snake moves exactly n−1n−1 times to the right and exactly n−1n−1 times downwards.

There are nn hidden snakes, with the ii-th snake having length ii for 1≤i≤n1≤i≤n, each moving independently according to the rule above. You do not know how the snakes move. Define f(l,T)f(l,T) as the maximum number that the snake with length ll covers at second TT.

Now, you are also given an integer mm. Your task is to find the mm smallest values of f(l,T)f(l,T), using at most 120n+m120n+m queries asking for the value of f(l,T)f(l,T) for some 1≤l≤n1≤l≤n and 1≤T≤2n−11≤T≤2n−1.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1001≤t≤100). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and mm (2≤n≤500,1≤m≤n(2n−1)2≤n≤500,1≤m≤n(2n−1)).

The following nn lines contain the grid GG. The ii-th of these lines contains nn integers Gi,1,Gi,2,…,Gi,nGi,1,Gi,2,…,Gi,n (1≤Gi,j≤n21≤Gi,j≤n2).

It is guaranteed that GG contains each number from 11 to n2n2 exactly once.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 500500, and the sum of mm over all test cases does not exceed 5⋅1045⋅104.

After you read the n+1n+1 lines of input, the interaction begins with your first query.

Interaction

To make a query, output a line in the following format (without the quotes):

  • "? lTlT" (1≤l≤n1≤l≤n, 1≤T≤2n−11≤T≤2n−1).

After each query, read in a single integer – the value of f(l,T)f(l,T). You may ask at most 120n+m120n+m queries of this type.

When you are ready to output the answer, print a line in the following format:

  • "! S1S2S3…SmS1S2S3…Sm" (1≤S1≤S2≤…≤Sm1≤S1≤S2≤…≤Sm).

This should contain the mm smallest values of f(l,T)f(l,T) in non-decreasing order. Note that this does not count towards the query limit.

After this, proceed to the next test case, or exit if this is the last test case.

If you make more than 120n+m120n+m queries during an interaction, your program must terminate immediately, and you will receive the Wrong Answer verdict. Otherwise, you can get an arbitrary verdict because your solution will continue to read from a closed stream.

After printing each line, do not forget to output the end of line and flush the output buffer. Otherwise, you will receive the Idleness Limit Exceeded verdict. To flush, use:

  • fflush(stdout) or cout.flush() in C++;
  • System.out.flush() in Java;
  • stdout.flush() in Python;
  • see the documentation for other languages.

Hacks

To make a hack, please use the following format:

The first line should contain the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1001≤t≤100).

The first line of each test case should contain two integers nn and mm (2≤n≤500,1≤m≤n(2n−1)2≤n≤500,1≤m≤n(2n−1)).

The following nn lines should each contain nn integers, giving information about the grid GG. The ii-th of these lines contains nn integers Gi,1,Gi,2,…,Gi,nGi,1,Gi,2,…,Gi,n (1≤Gi,j≤n21≤Gi,j≤n2).

Afterwards, for each of the nn snakes in increasing length, output a string slsl of length 2n−22n−2. The ii-th letter of slsl must denote the ii-th move of the snake of length ll, where 'R' denotes right and 'D' denotes downwards. For all 1≤l≤n1≤l≤n, the first letter of slsl must be 'D'.

For each ll, the string slsl must contain exactly n−1n−1 'R's and exactly n−1n−1 'D's.

The sum of nn over all test cases should not exceed 500500.

The sum of mm over all test cases should not exceed 5⋅1045⋅104.

For example, the hack format corresponding to the example interaction is as follows. 

1
3 15
4 2 5
1 9 3
7 6 8
DRDR
DDRR
DRRD
problems.noteHtml:
Below shows the tiles that the three snakes cover as they move across the grid.

The tiles covered by the first snake.
The tiles covered by the second snake.

The tiles covered by the third snake are shown in the statement above.
